facts: Public transit includes buses, trains, subways, trams, and ferries that many people can share instead of driving alone.
A full bus can take dozens of cars off the road, which helps reduce traffic jams in busy areas.
Many transit systems use electricity, and electric trains can be more energy-efficient per passenger than cars.
Riders often use a single ticket or pass to transfer between different routes, making it easier to travel across a city.
Some cities give buses their own lanes or traffic-signal priority so they can move faster and stay on schedule.
Transit maps are designed to be simple and easy to read, even if the routes are not drawn exactly to scale.
Public transit helps people who cannot drive, including younger students, older adults, and people with disabilities, reach school, jobs, and services.
sources_hint: You can verify these facts using transportation department sites, public transit agency rider guides, and basic energy and traffic information from educational resources.
